Jim, Tom - 

Maybe this suggestion is a little risky, but if the writing is on a flat surface, perhaps the careful use of a single-edged razor blade used at a low angle to the surface (so as not to scratch or "catch") would simply "pop off" the ink. Again, care must be taken so as not to scratch the surface patina. 

Ron
STL
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jim Gilbert 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, July 21, 2004 5:00 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kodogu kuestion


  Tom,
  I haven't had to deal with that.  I've found that isopropyl alcohol is "patina safe" and good for removing some of the junk that winds up on tsuba.  (Although if your tsuba has a patina "enhanced" by wax it will come off.)  I don't know if it'll work on sumi.  There is sumi ink remover for getting stains out of fibers:

  http://www.shodokai.com/shop/product_info.php?cPath=33_36_46&products_id=110&PHPSESSID=5766575043bd7ac2cb2e9b6ce3d12734

  I have no idea if it would work or if it would affect the patina.  My guess is that it's an enzymatic stain remover like Nature's Miracle.

  Sumi should be mostly carbon with some glue binder.    Since there's nothing for it to soak into here it may just come off with water and some brushing.

  Jim



    All-
          Yes yes, I'm back thank you very much, no applause please. Here is a 
    kodogu question for the group. How does one remove SUMI, as in india 
    ink, from iron, without of course damaging the patina. Sitting here 
    with a tsuba in my back pocket and my enquirin' mind wants to know...
    -t
